#UnitedAirlines:


Sentiment Anaylsis

A deeper look into Tweets

Try the Tweet Classifier!

Background

Since the founding of the first commercial airlines in 1909, humanity have come a long way in mass air transportation. With the emergence of multiple carriers serving similar routes, there has been an increasing need to differentiate and market each airline from its competitors. The paramount aspect of customer satisfaction is one such way. Social media has a growing influence on our purchase decision and should be taken into account by airlines management.

The analysis of Tweets is one such way to measure customer sentiment.


Problem Statement

To provide recommendations on specified areas of improvement for United Airlines based on passenger comments.

Data

These are the data sources for this project.

Twitter

Tweets containing 'United Airlines' were scraped using Twython from Twitter.

Kaggle

A Kaggle dataset on US Airlines Sentiment was used. Only tweets about United Airlines were filtered.

Link to Kaggle dataset

Methodology

These are the steps undertaken to evaluate the tweets.

Cleaning

After extracting the tweets using from the data sources, unnecessary text such as repeated tweets, '@' and '#' tags, urls, punctuation were removed and the remaining was changed to lower case.

Sentiment Analysis

VADER was first used to evaluate the tweets prior to removing punctuation and changing them to lower case. Subsequently, TextBlob was used to evaluate the sentiments after further cleaning was done.

Classification

LDA and Doc2Vec methods were first used but clear topics could not be identified. A second approach of checking for keywords in identified topics was used to label 3,322 tweets.

Insights

Below are the visualizations created after analysing the data.

Keywords based on training set

Keywords based on predicted set

WordCloud from Tweets

Recommendations

Manage passenger expectations during delays

Always respond quickly to passenger tweets and follow-up!

Educate staff on the pivotal role social media plays in customer service

Take ownership of customer problems!
